text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"Hey, everyone. I was promoted to a managerial role just a few months ago and I'm about to have a difficult conversation with one of my juniors, I'd love it if you can offer me some advice. Here's the situation. Our boss bought us a subscription to an AI writing assistant and some of our writers have started using it excessively to the extent they use the tool to generate entire articles. One of my best writers has fallen into this rut. We hired her because she was a good researcher who is capable of digging deep into a topic to draft comprehensive content, but right now the articles she turns in are pretty shallow and frankly copycat content. I wanna talk to her and address this without breaking the relationship I have built with her over the past few months. I would love to hear your thoughts on how I should proceed."

I think you should start off with why human-writing is better than AI-writing, preferably with examples. Take her through why you think she has a great knack for research that she should use for the better instead of relying on copycat content. And don’t forget to ask her questions about why she started over-relying on the tool in the first place. Too tight deadlines? Burnout? Something else? Hope this helps!

elements.text: I think you should start off with why human-writing is better than AI-writing, preferably with examples. Take her through why you think she has a great knack for research that she should use for the better instead of relying on copycat content. And don’t forget to ask her questions about why she started over-relying on the tool in the first place. Too tight deadlines? Burnout? Something else? Hope this helps!

text:
+1 to what Rochi said. I feel that many companies are unaware of the long-term risks producing heavily-AI-based content might have on SEO. Or, potentially, even content, where an AI tool generates the headings for each section based on existing articles, for that matter.

Search Engine Journal has just published a piece a couple weeks back, mentioning that AI written content is against Google’s rules and, if detected, will be treated as a violation of its guidelines. I think it’s worth sharing with the team: <https://www.searchenginejournal.com/google-says-ai-generated-content-is-against-guidelines/444916/#:~:text=Content%20generated%20automatically%20using%20AI,says%20Search%20Advocate%20John%20Mueller.&text=Google's%20Search%20Advocate%20John%20Mueller,the%20search%20engine's%20webmaster%20guidelines>.

text:
Offer support to the person and clear, objective feedback to the work output.

On the person side, is there something else going on that's leading to her overusing this tool? Is she struggling with something outside of work? Is her workload too heavy right now? Be candid and announce the fact that it's a hard conversation. Acknowledge that you don't want to damage the relationship you've built!

On the work output side, point out specific examples where the content needs to improve. Then circle back to the personal side and ask how you can help. As a manager, you're there to support the team, and honest feedback is just one part of that loop.

text:
You might want to provide more guidance on how the AI tool is supposed to be used. I always tell people that AI is your assistant, not another writer.
I usually tell people not to rely on AI for actual copy because even the sophisticated models are not great at it. For example, GPT-3 LOVES to write passive sentences. I actually asked GPT-3 directly why it does that and it told me it trained on writing with a lot of passive sentences :joy:
I really only use these tools for occasional rephrase when I’m stuck on a sentence and for outline ideas. I have to say, it’s 50/50 even on these simple tasks.

text: Joel is right. But also, wow, your prices are low! It might easier to do this off the bat with new clients, but I would say you could start new projects quoting higher rates, no explanation needed. A company that pays more is a company that sees the value in good content creators and how that helps their business. They're usually better to work with too.
